entries.fullText: DROWNING. - 1. Loosen clothing, if any. 2. Empty lungs of water by laying body in its stomach, and lifting it by the middle so that the head hangs down. Jerk the body a few times. 3. pull tongue forward, using handkerchief, or pin with string, if necessary. 4. Imitate motion of respiration by alternately compressing and expanding the lower ribs, about twenty times a minute. Alternately raising and lowering the arms from the sides up above the head will stimulate the action of the lungs. Let it be done gently by persistently. 5. Apply warmth and friction to extremities. 6. By holding tongue forward, closing the nostrils, and pressing the "Adam's apple" back (so as to close entrance to stomach), direct inflation may be tried. Take a deep breath and breathe it forcibly into the mouth of a patient, compress the chest to expel the air, and repeat the operation. 7. DON'T GIVE UP! People have been saved after HOURS of patient, vigorous effort. 8. When breathing begins, get patient into a warm bed, give WARM drinks, or spirits in teaspoonfuls, fresh air, and quiet.
entries.summaryText: Instructions on how to help someone who is drowning.

entries.fullText: SUNSTROKE. - There are two important indications for treatment - reduction of temperature and the use of stimulants. The patient should first be removed to a cooler spot if possible, or at least where shade can be secured. The treatment should be begun at once. The clothing about the neck and body must either be loosened or removed. Cold is particularly indicated in cases where there is great heat of the body, and delirium and convulsive movements are present. This means of reducing the temperature may be applied in the shape of cracked ice about the head and spine, or the use of cold water. If the head of the body is very great, it may be necessary to wrap the patient in sheets wet with cold water. If there is, besides great heat, evidence of serious depression, stimulants must be used while the cold is being applied.
entries.summaryText: Instructions on how to treat someone with sunstroke.

entries.fullText: HAEMORRHAGE. - The usual treatment is rest in the recumbent position; small pieces of ice should be freely swallowed, and the application of ice wrapped in a towel or in an ice-bag, or snow, cold water, etc., over the stomach; hot applications may be applied to the extremities.
entries.summaryText: Instructions on how to treat someone with hemorrhage.

entries.fullText: FIRE IN A BUILDING. - Crawl on the floor. The clearest air is the lowest in the room. Cover head with woolen wrap, wet if possible. Cut holes for the eyes. Don't get excited.
entries.summaryText: Instructions on what to do in case of a fire in a building.

entries.fullText: BURNS AND SCALDS. - Cover with cooking soda and lay wet cloths over it. Whites of eggs and olive oil. Olive oil or linseed oil, plain or mixed with chalk or whiting. Sweet or olive oil and lime-water. Shock, which is always present in severe burns, requires the administration of stimulants. Pain is more constant and intense in burns than in any other form of injury, and requires sedatives, which should be administered by the medical attendant. Later on the appearances of inflammation and other complications are to be carefully watched for.
entries.summaryText: Instructions on how to treat burns and scalds.

entries.fullText: SUFFOCATION FROM INHALING ILLUMINATING GAS. - Get into the fresh air as soon as possible and lie down. Keep warm. Take ammonia - twenty drops to a tumbler of warm water, at frequent intervals; also, two to four drops tincture of nux vomica every hour or two for five or six hours.
entries.summaryText: Instructions on what to do in case of suffocation from inhaling illuminating gas.

entries.fullText: TESTS OF DEATH. - Hold mirror to mouth. If living, moisture will gather. Push pin into flesh. If dead, the hole will remain; if alive, it will close up. Place fingers in front of a strong light. If alive, they will appear red; if dead, black or dark.
entries.summaryText: Instructions on how to test if someone is dead.

entries.fullText: MAD DOG OR SNAKE-BITE. - Tie cord tight above wound. Suck the wound or cauterize with caustic or white-hot iron at once, or cut out adjoining parts with a sharp knife. Give stimulants, as whisky, brandy, etc.
entries.summaryText: Instructions on what to do in case of a mad dog or snake bite.

entries.fullText: FIRE IN ONE'S CLOTHING. - Don't run - especially not downstairs or out-of-doors. Roll on carpet, or wrap in woolen rug or blanket. Keep the head down, so as not to inhale flame.
entries.summaryText: Instructions on what to do in case of a fire in one's clothing.

entries.fullText: FIRE FROM KEROSENE. - Don't use water, it will spread the flames. Dirt, sand, or flour is the best extinguisher, or smother with woolen rug, table-cloth, or carpet.
entries.summaryText: Instructions on what to do in case of a fire from kerosene.

entries.fullText: CINDERS IN THE EYE. - Roll soft paper up like a lamp lighter, and wet the tip to remove, or use a medicine dropper to draw it out. Rub the other eye.
entries.summaryText: Instructions on what to do in case of cinders in the eye.

entries.fullText: FAINTING. - Place flat on back; allow fresh air, and sprinkle with water. Place head lower than rest of body.
entries.summaryText: Instructions on what to do in case of fainting.

entries.fullText: STINGS OF VENOMOUS INSECTS, ETC. - Apply weak ammonia, oil, salt water, or iodine.
entries.summaryText: Instructions on what to do in case of stings of venomous insects.

entries.fullText: LIGHTNING. - Dash cold water over a person struck.
entries.summaryText: Instructions on what to do in case of lightning strike.

entries.fullText:
POISONS AND ANTIDOTES

FIRST. -- Send for a physician.
SECOND. -- INDUCE VOMITING, by tickling throat with feather or finger. Drink hot water or strong mustard and water. Swallow sweet oil or whites of eggs.

Acids are antidotes for alkalies, and vice versa.

ACIDS, MINERAL -- Chalk, magnesia (plaster off wall in emergency), solution carbonate of soda, emollient drinks, fixed oils.

ACID, CARBOLIC -- Any soluble sulphate, such as magnesia.

ACID, HYDROCYANIC -- Fresh air and artificial respiration, with cold effusion. Ammonia by inhalation and intravenously in vein of leg.

ACONITE -- Emetics, stimulants, external and internal: keep up external heat, keep flat on back.

ANTIMONY TART -- Vegetable acids, such as tannic acid, catechu.

ARSENIC -- Freshly precipitated hydrated sesquioxide of iron made by adding magnesia to any iron solution.

ATROPIA -- Same as Belladonna.

BELLADONNA -- Emetics -- mustard flour in water; give physostigma or pilocarpine; cold to head.

CANTHARIDES -- Emetics, emollient drinks, opiates by mouth and rectum, large draughts of water to flush kidneys.

CHLORINE WATER -- Albumen, white of egg, milk, flour.

CHLOROFORM -- Fresh air, artificial respiration (inclining head down, pull tongue forward), brandy and ammonia intravenously in leg, the HYPODERMIC injection of 15 M, tincture of digitalis and I-60 of a grain of atropine.

COLCHICUM -- Emetics, followed by demulcent drinks. If come be present brandy, ammonia, coffee. Opium in large dose. Keep up external heat.

CONIUM -- Emetics, followed by stimulants external and internal.

CORROSIVE SUBLIMATE -- Albumen, white of egg (4 gr. sublimate require white of one egg), flour, milk. Equal parts of lime water and milk. Emetics, or evacuate stomach by pump.

COPPER SULPH -- Yellow prussiate of potash or soap.

CROTON OIL -- Emetics, wash out stomach, followed by mucilaginous fluids, containing opium.

DIGITALIS -- Recumbent posture after emetics. Emetics and opium: give tincture aconite.

ELATERIUM -- Demulcent drinks, enemeta of opium, and external heat.

HYOSCYAMUS -- Stomach pump, emetics, stimulants external and internal, physostigma and pilocarpine.

ILLUMINATING GAS -- Hypodermic injections of nitroglycerin are recommended by Kloman, of Baltimore.

IODINE -- Emetics and demulcent drinks, starch or flour diffused in water, opium and external heat.

LEAD SALTS -- Any soluble sulphate, either magnesia or soda, succeeded by emetics, and afterwards by opium and milk.

LOBELLA -- Stimulants externally and internally; external heat.

MORPHINE -- Same as opium.

NUX VOMICA -- 30 grs. of chloral and 60 grs. of bromide of potash. Nitrite of amyl.

OPIUM -- Atropine hypodermically till respirations number 8 per minute. Stomach pump, stimulants, external and internal, brandy and coffee, cold affusion, ammonia to nostrils, galvanic shocks, compelling to move about, artificial respiration, electric brush. Permanganate of Potash.

OXALIC ACID -- Lime, not potash or soda.

PHOSPHORUS -- Sulphate of copper in emetic dose as chemical antidote. No oils. Emetics and purgatives.

POTASH AND SODA SALTS -- Dilute acetic acid, citric acid, lemon juice, fixed oils, demulcents, vinegar.

SILVER NITRATE -- Solution of common salt and demulcent drinks. Emetics.

STRAMONIUM -- Same as Belladonna.

STRYCHNINE -- Same as Nux Vomica.

TOBACCO -- Emetic, stimulants, external and internal, strychnine, external heat.

ZINC SALTS -- Carbonate of soda, emetics, warm demulcent drinks.
entries.summaryText: A list of poisons and their antidotes, along with instructions on how to induce vomiting and other emergency procedures.

entries.fullText: At home. A 2 PM. went to Mrs Jullam's - 21 Windsor st - to have new black satin fitted - or it's lining
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony went to Mrs Jullam's to have new black satin fitted.

entries.fullText: Wea. THUR. JAN 6. 1898 Ther.

At home - working
on [?] - books all
of this week - not
even making a call
on anyone since evening
on Tuesday P. U. to by
on [?????] at Mrs. Williams

B[ig]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony has been working on books all week and has not made any calls since Tuesday evening. She plans to go to Mrs. Williams' place.

entries.fullText:
At home -
Miss [Bath?] finished the
last year's - 1897 scrap
this A.M. & began type
writing my 4th of July
speech at Ottumwa - Kansas
in 1865! on Pres Johnsons
re-construction proclamation
of Mississippi!! -
Mrs. Harper grinding away on
last half of 1896 - California
chap - Miss Hanley & Meilke
copying the early chapters of
of the last 15 - for the book -
- Letter from dear Rachel Foster
saying she must give up her Con. sec'y
office & devote herself to her home and
children - I wrote her a four
page reply - of what I felt the cause
- It made almost ill!
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about working on her 4th of July speech, receiving a letter from Rachel Foster, and Mrs. Harper working on a chapter about California.

entries.fullText:
At Home--
Sister Mary went Church--
Mrs. Harper to tea with
Mrs Haberly & her intended--
Miss Hawley [under?] this day--
Miss Rathbone to church in evening--
I wrote 24 letters--[Lende?]
reading the papers--
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her daily activities, including writing letters and reading the papers.

entries.dateText:
At home - rain all day -

P.E. Club sociable at Mr &
Ms James Sargents -
98 East Avenue
entries.fullText:
At home - rain all day -

P.E. Club sociable at Mr &
Ms James Sargents -
98 East Avenue
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was at home all day due to rain. She attended a P.E. Club sociable at Mr and Ms James Sargents' house located at 98 East Avenue.

entries.fullText: The last letter of Frances E. Willard to S.B.A. was written- & dictated this day- at Hotel Empire, New York - in reply to my earnest invitation for her "not to dare go through Rochester without stopping to visit us" - this was forwarded to her-- from Evanston--
entries.summaryText: Frances E. Willard wrote a letter to S.B.A. at Hotel Empire in New York in response to an invitation to visit in Rochester.

entries.fullText:
Severe snow storm
Tired as always in
trying to close up
things & get ready to
leave home
Miss Backus for Bonnet
Mrs. Fillans - making
new figured satin,
making over helmet--
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about a severe snow storm and her preparations to leave home. She also mentions Miss Backus and Mrs. Fillans.

entries.fullText:
N. Y. State grange to meet
at Syracuse & I am invited
to speak before them this P.M.-
Left R. on 9.05 train -
no the Limited- that should
have passed at 6 A.M. the
snow - the blizzard - belates
all trains - found H. M.
Mills at station - went home
with her to [discussion?]- & at
4 P.M. went to Empire
Hotel - a hall over it - & spoke
for 20 minutes - crowded
house - Then went back
& spent night
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about being invited to speak at the N. Y. State grange meeting in Syracuse. She also mentions the snow storm delaying trains and spending the night at a hotel.

entries.fullText:
Left Syracuse at
11- on limited that
should have passed
4 hours before - so had
to pay 1.75 extra which with
the 50 cts yesterday - meant 2.50
extra - reached New York
at 6 - Found cousin
Samantha, cousin Carrie
[Nail?] Ladd - Miss Rockwell
& the house keeper Miss
Powell at supper - had
a good visit
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left Syracuse and arrived in New York to visit her cousin Samantha and other acquaintances.

entries.fullText:
In New York
Cousin Samantha sent
me over to Mrs. Stantons
at 10. A.M. in carriage
where I spent day, & she
came for me at 5.30
Sister Mary wrote
that Mrs D. Jones, wife
of (Dr. Jonas Jones) - died
this night - in her home -
corner of Madison street &
West Avenue - very
sudden - I had not
known of her illness -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spent the day at Mrs. Stanton's house in New York and received news of the sudden death of Mrs. D. Jones.

entries.fullText:
Cousin S. Sent me over
To Mrs. Stantons in carriage
again- called at
Hotel Empire- to see
Frances Willard- who,
Mrs. Stanton had told me
was there & too ill to see
any- yet it felt I must
at least call & let her
Anna Gordon know I
thought of them - but
Miss W. Sent word it would
do her eyes good to see me
so Anna took me to her
room & there she lay. Face &
hands white as the linens that
surrounded them. But bright
& chippery, like herself- making
feel she might rise out of it-
Worked the day with Mrs. S,
but her educated suffrage is so
fastened on her brain - she can think
of nothing else.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Mrs. Stantons and Frances Willard at Hotel Empire in New York.

entries.fullText:
Left- New York on the
10:50 train - Nicholas
Met me at market street
Station. Took me to 119 South
19th st. Where dear Rachel
& she and the two children live in
three little rooms - at 5 Burt
came and went with me to
Louise. 4716. [?] Ave.
Anna O. Came to tea-
& we had a nice visit -
Mr. James at home.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony leaves New York and visits Rachel in Philadelphia.

entries.fullText:
Left Philadelphia on
11 train - found niece
Lucy E at station &
we took her to the
Regent Hotel - found
that Mrs. Upton would
arrive that night -
- Mrs. May L. Sperry
& daughter Melba
from San Francisco
had come on sooner
that anticipated - so
had a nice visit
with them
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left Philadelphia and met with her niece Lucy E at the station. They went to the Regent Hotel where they met Mrs. Upton and Mrs. May L. Sperry and her daughter Melba from San Francisco. They had a nice visit.

entries.fullText:
At the Regent
Mrs Upton -Mrs.
Sherry & self - Made
several calls on
M. C. families &
at 7 P.M. Mrs Sherry
& daughter left for
Old Point Comfort
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony stayed at the Regent with Mrs. Upton and Mrs. Sherry. They made several calls on M.C. families. At 7 P.M. Mrs. Sherry and her daughter Melba left for Old Point Comfort.

entries.fullText: In Washington at 7 p.m. - Mrs. Samuel B. Gross & two nieces - Minnie & Emma Campbell arrived - from Chicago - & all went into a great corner room with fine windows Mrs Upton & self made Cabinet Calls this P.M.
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Samuel B. Gross and her two nieces arrived from Chicago and met with Mrs. Upton and Susan B. Anthony to make Cabinet Calls.

entries.fullText: In Wash--at request Mrs. Gross, Mrs. Upton, Mrs Sperry & self made Senatorial calls--
entries.summaryText: At the request of Mrs. Gross, Susan B. Anthony, Mrs. Upton, and Mrs. Sperry made Senatorial calls in Washington.

entries.fullText:
In Wash - at Regent-

Miss Clay - Blanchard
Rachel & Nicolas -
Mrs Catt - Miss Hay - &
others came this
P.M. Mrs. Swift - of
California - who took
but a glimpse of the
Regent - turned on her
heels & went to the
Shoreham -
Had a preliminary
? meeting this
evening -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is in Washington D.C. at the Regent hotel. She meets with several people including Mrs. Swift of California. They have a preliminary meeting in the evening.

entries.fullText:
In Wash--
Miss Shaw came
this noon--
Begun business
meetings in dead
earnest this P.M.
& evening--
Lucy E. working
like a trojan all
these days to get
things in order
with the program
& Hall--Mrs
Upton with the
papers
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is still in Washington D.C. and begins business meetings in earnest. Lucy E. is working hard to get things in order with the program and Hall. Mrs. Upton is with the papers.

entries.fullText:
Miss Shaw to Preach
in Columbia Theatre this
afternoon at O. O’clock-
Business Meeting -
Without Miss Shaw -
this A. M. - & in
evn’g - a long session
- a fine audience
at Miss Shaw’s sermon
entries.summaryText: Miss Shaw preached at Columbia Theatre and there was a business meeting without her in the morning and a long session in the evening. There was a fine audience at Miss Shaw's sermon.

entries.fullText:
Columbia Theatre - no -
? Regent
entries.summaryText: There is a mention of Columbia Theatre and a Regent in Washington D.C.

entries.fullText:
50th Anniversary of 1st W. A. Con at Seneca Falls
Mrs. J. B. McLean gave 98th Birth Day Luncheon to me - had 50 guests - in? of our girls, Mrs Swift, - Mrs Osborne, Mrs Harper, Mrs Sewell, Mrs Conine, -
Wea. WED. FEB. 16, 1898. Ther. ? 0th Wash. Con -
At the Regent -
entries.summaryText: Attended 50th Anniversary of 1st W. A. Con at Seneca Falls and Mrs. J. B. McLean's 98th Birth Day Luncheon.

entries.fullText:
Miss Willard passed
to the beyond this evening(?)
about 12-
entries.summaryText: Miss Willard passed away at around midnight.

entries.fullText:
Regent Hotel-
the Associated Press this
A.M. announced the death
of Frances E. Willard - at -
midnight - last night -
at Empire Hotel - New York
City with only Miss Anna
Gordon - Ms S.M. Stevens &
two or three W.G.F.N women
all too soon gone - but
not lost from us--
-- A telegram come to
me from Anna Gordon -
saying-- Frances passed
"entered the higher
Ministries!! last night
what a stripping of her stay & staff to dear Anna
entries.summaryText: Frances E. Willard passed away at Empire Hotel in New York City. Anna Gordon sent a telegram saying that she had entered the higher Ministries.

entries.fullText: Wea. TUES., MARCH 15, 1898 Ther.

Took 9.05 train for
Syracuse - found Miss
Mills at station - called
at Jules Hotel - found
Mrs. May Wood Swift
of San Francisco had
arrived the P.M before -
& preferred to remain - . I
went to Mrs May Bigelow
Phillips - 903 West Seneca st --
found her brother's wife &
friend there - for the evening
entertainment at the P.E. Club --
- took a sleep - & at
8 Oclock - with Miss & Mrs
Mills - Mrs Swift went to the
J. & E. Union Hall - spoke & chatted
with Mrs Sedgewick, Mrs. Miller
& all -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Syracuse and meets with Miss Mills and Mrs. May Wood Swift. She also visits Mrs May Bigelow Phillips and attends an evening entertainment at the P.E. Club with her brother's wife and friend. Later, she goes to the J. & E. Union Hall with Miss Mills and Mrs Swift and speaks with Mrs Sedgewick and Mrs. Miller.

entries.fullText: Mrs. Swift & self took Empire Note train N 2.15- & arrived Rochester - 2.25 - found front chamber pretty well cleared - and in good order - Mrs Harper going into the little back bedroom - & Miss Rathburn sleeping on sofa bed in my sitting room - - Mrs Swift settled down to a quiet nice visit at ?-
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Swift visits Rochester and stays in Susan B. Anthony's house.

entries.fullText: At home ?ing in book- Matilda Joslyn Gage died this day - was stricken with paralysis last Sunday - her son Clarkson wrote - before she yet had passed on- Talked all ?day with Mrs Swift over California & all therein- & 1895 -& 1896 campaigns -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony stays at home and talks with Mrs. Swift about California and the 1895-1896 campaigns. Matilda Joslyn Gage dies.

entries.fullText: At home. Reporter of Post. Express called - & I gave him interview on Mrs Gage - which appeared in this P.M. paper & Dem & Chron. reported Mrs Hair came in in evening - & hers appeared during A.M. paper the [?]. Mrs Greenleaf to supper with us -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony gave an interview to a reporter about Mrs. Gage, Mrs. Hair visited in the evening, and Mrs. Greenleaf had supper with them.

entries.fullText: At home. Mrs. Swift went to Unitarian church with me - & Mr. Garrett preached on war
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attended church with Mrs. Swift and heard Mr. Garrett preach about war.

entries.fullText:
Mrs. Greenleaf carriage
round - Mrs. Swift, Mrs.
Harper & self -- went
out -- East Avenue &c
At supper we had
Mr. and Mrs. Gannett -- Mrs.
Montgomery, Mrs. Sanford
& Mrs. Hoyt -- which with
our own made ten at table
-- a very pleasant time --
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Greenleaf, Mrs. Swift, Mrs. Harper, Mr. and Mrs. Gannett, Mrs. Montgomery, Mrs. Sanford, Mrs. Hoyt had supper together at East Avenue.

entries.fullText:
At home
Letter this A.M. said
Miss Shaw would
arrive this evening - so
Mrs. Swift decided to
stop over another day -
- Miss Shaw came
at six -- & glad
enough was I that
Mrs. Swift could
have a good time
with her --
entries.summaryText: Miss Shaw arrived and Mrs. Swift stayed another day to spend time with her.

entries.fullText:
At home -
Miss Shaw & Mrs Swift
had the whole day
to themselves -
Mrs Hallowell
& Mrs Willis came
to tea - I wanted
Mrs Swift to see the
two women who had
stood by me personally
for the whole 50 years -
At 9 - Miss Shaw, Mrs
Harper & self rode over
to Station with Mrs Swift
&saw her off on Business
matter at first - & then
to Indianapolis - to visit
Mrs Sewell - & then
on to San Franciso
entries.summaryText: Miss Shaw and Mrs. Swift had the whole day to themselves while Mrs. Hallowell and Mrs. Willis came to tea. Miss Shaw, Mrs. Harper, and Susan B. Anthony saw Mrs. Swift off on a business matter to Indianapolis to visit Mrs. Sewell and then on to San Francisco.

entries.fullText:
Miss Shaw read
chapters of the
Book -
entries.summaryText: Miss Shaw read chapters of the Book at home.

entries.fullText:
Miss Shaw reading
chapters all day -
entries.summaryText: Miss Shaw spent the day reading chapters at home.

entries.fullText:
DONNELLY– In this city, March 26, 1898,
Sarah F. Donnelly, sister of Mary E., M.
Louise and Arthur E. Donnelly, a native of
San Francisco.
Friends are respectfully invited to at-
tend the funeral to-morrow (Monday), at 10
o'clock, from 815 Oak street., thence to Sa-
cred heart Church. Interment Holy Cross
Cemetery. Kindly omit flowers.
entries.summaryText: Sarah F. Donnelly passed away and her funeral is to be held the next day.

entries.fullText:
DUCK– In this city, March 25, 1898, John
Duck, brother of Mrs. Margaret Burns, and
uncle of Mary, Patrick and John Burns, a native
of County Roscommon, Ireland, aged
66 years.
Friends and acquaintances are respect-
fully invited to attend the funeral this day
(Sunday), at 8:30 o'clock, from his late resi-
dence, 342 Cumberland street, thence to Mis-
sion Dolores Church, Sixteenth and Dolores
streets, where a requiem high mass will be
celebrated for the repose of his soul, com-
mencing at 9 o'clock. Interment Holy Cross
Cemetery.
entries.summaryText: John Duck passed away and his funeral is to be held on the same day.

entries.fullText:
At home -
early breakfast -
and I went in carriage
with Miss Shaw - &
saw her roll off
westward at 7.20 -
for Warren Ohio -
where she will stay
to night & go to her
Monday night’s lecture
Mary, Mrs Harper
& self dined? at Mary
Hallowells- they were greatly
disappointed that Miss Shaw
had to leave this A.M. -
but I am Not it was the
wise thing for her to do -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends time with Miss Shaw before she leaves for Warren Ohio. She then has dinner with Mary and Mrs. Harper.

entries.fullText:
at home -
Pitched into going
over chapters with
Mrs Harper again in
good earnest - was
a good -deal shirking?
the last ten days -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends the day at home and works on chapters with Mrs. Harper.

entries.fullText:
At home
[?] an 86.00 [?]
Mrs W. B. Morse
called - had
been at 3
funerals- one
Mrs Alfred Wright’s
mother - 88 - Mrs
Butterfield
- -
entries.summaryText: Mrs W. B. Morse visited and had been to three funerals, including Mrs Alfred Wright's mother and Mrs Butterfield.

entries.summaryText: Journal entry on April 1, 1898, written at home.

entries.fullText: Letter from Clara M. Schlinghegde - San Francisco, Cal. dated March 28th here this A. M. saying Miss Sarah Donnelly - died March 25th Saturday - & was buried Monday the 28th cause a rupture from striving to close folding doors - back of her piano -at which she was singing - “Say Au Revoir” - but but not good Bye” there are left Mary & Louise - the latter almost blind - having suffered tortures with treatment the last four months or more - sad - had no such bright force - ever came into suffrage office there in 1896!!
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony receives a letter from Clara M. Schlinghegde in San Francisco, informing her of the death of Miss Sarah Donnelly due to a rupture while closing folding doors. Only Mary and Louise are left, the latter almost blind and having suffered for the last four months. Susan expresses sadness and remembers the bright force that Miss Donnelly was in the suffrage office in 1896.
Susan B. Anthony writes a short entry stating that she is at home on Sunday, April 3, 1898.

entries.fullText:
At home -
Mrs Austni ?erry & daughter
Beda of San Francisco-
arrived on Empire Note
train - Mrs Sweet & self met
them - Mr & Mrs Sweet
called in the evening also -
entries.summaryText: Mrs Austni ?erry and daughter Beda from San Francisco arrived on Empire Note train and were met by Mrs Sweet and Susan B. Anthony at home. Mr and Mrs Sweet also called in the evening.

entries.fullText:
Ther. at Home
Mrs. and Miss Sperry with us
Mrs Sweet here to
dinner - expecting to
take a drive but
the weather too cloudy.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends the day at home with Mrs. and Miss Sperry and Mrs. Sweet. They plan to take a drive but the weather is too cloudy.

entries.fullText:
Ther. at home
The Sperrys with us-
they went to luncheon
Mrs Thom - formerly
Miss James - Hiram Davis
--
and at 6 P.M.
I joined them at dinner
with Mrs Sweet - Mr &
Mrs Gannett there also
raining & sloppy
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends the day at home with the Sperrys. They go to luncheon with Mrs. Thom, formerly Miss James, and Hiram Davis. Later, Susan joins them for dinner with Mrs. Sweet and Mr. and Mrs. Gannett despite the rainy and sloppy weather.

entries.fullText:
Ready - Reading -
Mrs & Miss Sperry with us
they went down to
see Mrs Sweet in her
Bank - Security Trust Co --
For the P.M. the
Sperrys took a nice
drive with Mr & Mrs
Sweet -- he driving
entries.summaryText: Reading at home with Mrs & Miss Sperry. They visited Mrs Sweet at her bank, and later went on a drive with Mr & Mrs Sweet.

entries.fullText:
Sister Mary went to
Church - Mrs Harper
Miss Hawley & self - & part
of the time sister May
reading proof copy all day -
Mrs. Sperry & Beda went
to Church - Unitarian with May
- & thence to dinner with
Mr & Mrs Sweet - then
called at the Gannetts
& reached us about 7
it rained during P.M.
entries.summaryText: Attended church and read proof copy with Sister May. Mrs. Sperry and Beda went to a different church and had dinner with Mr & Mrs Sweet. Visited the Gannetts in the evening.

entries.fullText:
At home
Reading copy for last
time --
Mrs. Mary Simpson
Sperry & daughter Beda --
left on 8.15 train -- I
went to station with them
Mrs Sweet there, husband also
They stop at Niagara Falls
until 6 p.m. Then go on
to Chicago for a few days

Several friends called
this evening -- Dr. & Mrs. Willis
& daughter Mrs. Linn - &
I just had to refuse
to leave the book work
to go down -- though it
was my night to be
free to see all who came.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her day at home, seeing off Mrs. Mary Simpson Sperry and her daughter Beda, who are traveling to Niagara Falls and Chicago. She also mentions several friends who visited her in the evening.

entries.fullText:
At home
Mrs Harper & self --
with Missees Hanley & Rathburn
reading for last time the
closing chapters of the Biog
all the day long until
10 o'clock evening sharp - enough
put out the eyes of each
& all --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends the day at home with Mrs. Harper, Misses Hanley, and Rathburn, reading the closing chapters of a biography until 10 pm.

entries.fullText:
Finished reading &
revising the last of the
50 chapters with Preface -
this evening- It seems
like getting out of a
long night-more agony -
I hope no one
mentioned in the book
will feel there was a
willingness on my part
to permit Mrs Harper
to be unjust to her - but
I greatly fear my very nearest
friends & helpers will feel
I should not have allowed
any mentions of differences
between them & me - but
we shall see -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony finished reading and revising the last of the 50 chapters with Preface and expressed concern that her friends and helpers may feel she should not have allowed any mentions of differences between them and her.

entries.fullText:
Miss Amy Rathbun-
of Avoca - left this P.M.
she has been a faithful
worker for me the past
Seven weeks - & for
weeks prior -
At 5 - Sister May & self
called at Mrs W. A. Mercer
reception- a great company
At 7.00 - we went by
George & Mrs Smith’s -
P. S. Club Sociable-
nice time - Dr. Porter Farley
read every paper against W. S.
making the hackneyed charge that
we taught no marrying to women
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony's assistant, Miss Amy Rathbun, left after seven weeks of faithful work. Susan attended a reception at Mrs. W. A. Mercer's and a P.S. Club Sociable at George and Mrs. Smith's where Dr. Porter Farley read papers against W. S. making the hackneyed charge that they taught no marrying to women.

entries.fullText:
At Home
Mrs Harper doing
up last jobs -
on corrections of copy -
the bonnet or hat getting-
shoes - R.R. Ticket &c
- she also called on
Saturday P. M. on Mrs
Hallowell & Mrs Milles
& they drove her to
Mr Sargents to make
her parting call -
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Harper is finishing up work and making parting calls.

entries.fullText:
At Home
All day - Mrs Harper -
packing trunks- having
Miss Hawley to assist her the
entire day - & Miss Hawley
& little Annie Dann - going
with her - Mrs Harper to her
Lehigh Valley train at 10.15 oclock
- I dictated letters to
Miss Meilke - but to very
poor account - mind too
full of last years worries
& works - to allow of my
concentration on the present -
This closes Mrs Harpers
staying in our house - since
the first week of February 1897 -
to the 21st of April - 1898- she
being absent about 2 1/2 months -
Jul. Aug. Sept. - so that she has
given fully ten months to the
closest kind of work to this
Biography -& I have done ditto - and
not altogether neglected suffrage
Work meantime- either
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Harper finishes packing and leaves after staying for over a year to work on the biography.

entries.fullText:
-
At Home -
Sister May & self -
with our little Canadian
girl Annie L. Dann -
now constitute the regular
family - - and it
as after a long sickness
death & funeral is ones
family - so still - and
so empty handed- & yet
the work is immeasurable
that awaits the doing -
Read Hearsts Sunday Journal
war with Spain is now begun
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is at home with her sister and a Canadian girl named Annie L. Dann. They read Hearsts Sunday Journal and learn that the war with Spain has begun.

entries.fullText:
-
At Home -
Begin to day - with Miss
Genevieve Lel Hawley
of Canjoharie - as my one
stenographer, type writer and
doer of whatever I need to
have done pertaining to my
correspondence & association with
private & general -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony begins working with Miss Genevieve Lel Hawley of Canjoharie as her stenographer, typewriter, and assistant for her correspondence and general association.

entries.fullText:
At Home
National Conference
[Penhal?] Church--
Mrs. Catt & Miss Clay
at Mrs [Sweets?]
Mrs Eliza Wright
Osborn came at 1.50--
& Miss Shaw at 6.50
Small audience--
considering the church--the
work done & the speakers
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about a small audience at the National Conference held at [Penhal?] Church. She mentions the attendees including Mrs. Catt, Miss Clay, Mrs. [Sweets?], Mrs. Eliza Wright, Osborn, and Miss Shaw.

entries.fullText: Went to Central Station & met Mrs Ellen Clark Sargent & Dr Elizabeth - from Boston - they were rejoiced to find Miss Shaw here - Miss Shaw preached in Ashbury M. E. Church - on East Avenue - and Mrs. Catt gave lecture in the Unitarian Church - both had good audiences & made good sermons - every one delighted - the Sargents & self remained at home
entries.summaryText: Attended church services and lectures with Mrs. Ellen Clark Sargent, Dr. Elizabeth, Miss Shaw, and Mrs. Catt in various locations in the city.

entries.fullText: Went to Central Station & met Mrs Ellen Clark Sargent & Dr Elizabeth - from Boston - they were rejoiced to find Miss Shaw here - Miss Shaw preached in Ashbury M. E. Church - on East Avenue - and Mrs. Catt gave lecture in the Unitarian Church - both had good audiences & made good sermons - every one delighted - the Sargents & self remained at home
entries.summaryText: Attended church services and lectures with Mrs. Ellen Clark Sargent, Dr. Elizabeth, Miss Shaw, and Mrs. Catt in various locations in the city.

entries.fullText:
At Home--
Dark & cloudy--
Mrs. Shaw spent
her day with us
visiting with the Sargents & writing
her letters--
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Shaw spent the day visiting with the Sargents and writing letters.

entries.fullText:
At Home
Raining all the day
at six I went with
Mrs. & Dr. Lizzie Sargent
to supper with Mr.
& Mrs. Sweet--drizzly
weather--but Mrs
Sweet can keep bright
& chatty with it all--
Mrs. Catt & Miss Hay
came back from Oswego
where they had rain, rain
& small cold audiences---
Left Miss Shaw to finish
up this evenings work alone
Miss Shaw took the
8.45 train for Oswego
entries.summaryText: Mrs. & Dr. Lizzie Sargent went to supper with Mr. & Mrs. Sweet in the rain. Mrs. Catt & Miss Hay returned from Oswego with small cold audiences. Miss Shaw took the 8.45 train for Oswego.

entries.fullText:
At Home -
in forenoon Dr. Eliz.
& Mrs Sargent & self went
to see the upper & then
the lower falls - but
the rain began again -
- At 11.30 Miss Shaw
came- & she visited
with the Sargents - &
at 9.30 we two went to
the station & saw the
Sargents off for San
Francisco - on the Forest
Shore & Nikel Plate Line -
-This makes three family
visits from San Francisco
friends - Mrs Swift, Mrs &
Miss Sperry, Mrs. & Dr. Sargent
during April & first week of May
glad to see them all - but
the two first came in the midst of
book work & the last in my collapse of it
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits the upper and lower falls with Dr. Eliz and Mrs. Sargent, sees Miss Shaw, and sees the Sargents off for San Francisco.

entries.fullText:
At Home
Went to Central Station
with Miss Shaw for the
10.10 train for Elmira -
where Conference is in
process - began to rain
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony goes to the Central Station with Miss Shaw to catch a train to Elmira where a conference is in process.

entries.fullText: At Home
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote that she was at home.

entries.fullText:
At home -
at 2.30 - went alone
to the Lyceum Theatre
to see the Historic
Tableaux gotten up by
Mrs Charles Fitch - very
few present - the whole
receipt of performances
has been at a loss - So
we did actually better
than the show -
Went to Mrs. Harriet
Bowkers to get bonnet
fixed so it wouldn't
swing off to the left
side of head - but it
was no better
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony went to the Lyceum Theatre to see the Historic Tableaux and then to Mrs. Harriet Bowkers to get her bonnet fixed, but it was no better.

entries.fullText:
At Home--
Sister Mary & self went
to church--Mr. Garnetts
subject--"Enthusiasm"--
inspiration --[inclination?]--
Dr Rachel Gleason of
Elmira Water Cure--
dressed in complete suit
of gray--78 years of age
& her only daughter Dr
Adelle Gleason--sat on
front seat--sh'd not
know either--after supper
I went over to Mr Garnetts
& spent an hour or so with
the Gleasons & Dr. Sarah Dolley--
no news from anybody--
& the papers tell only of
the war of the [?] of
rebuffing the Spaniards
both at sea & land--
entries.summaryText: Attended church with Sister Mary and Mr. Garnett, saw Dr. Rachel Gleason and Dr. Adelle Gleason at the Elmira Water Cure, and spent time with the Gleasons and Dr. Sarah Dolley.

entries.fullText:
At Home
trying to get settled
so as to set about work
entries.summaryText: Trying to get settled at home to start work.

entries.fullText:
Letter from niece
Maude--saying her
husband--Lieut. Louis
Koebler had been ordered
to Tampa--she is at
home--with her mother
entries.summaryText: Received a letter from Maude, my niece, informing me that her husband, Lieut. Louis Koebler, had been ordered to Tampa. She is now at home with her mother.
No entry written.

entries.fullText: Sister Mary & self attended Church supper 2 Annual meetig - pleasant gathrg Marked in attic nearly all the day - WEnt over to Mrs Fullams to be measure for Tea Gown Garnet ribbed silk - vy pretty -
entries.summaryText: Sister Mary and Susan B. Anthony attended a church supper and marked in the attic. Susan went to Mrs. Fullam's to be measured for a garnet ribbed silk tea gown.

entries.fullText: I worked all day in the back attic - with Genevieve - trying to put things where she would know & find them rec'd reply from Mrs Patter Palmer Hotel du Rhin - 4 - 6 Chase Vendome Paris France Sug'g she would accept positin of representative of all womens societies at the Paris expositin of 1900 - Sent it to May Wright Sewell - I do hope we can get the President to appoint Mrs Palmer
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony worked in the attic with Genevieve. She received a reply from Mrs. Patter Palmer who suggested she would accept a position as representative of all women's societies at the Paris exposition of 1900. Susan sent the suggestion to May Wright Sewell and hopes to get the President to appoint Mrs. Palmer.

entries.fullText:
Went down town
Put Mrs Husseys 2d $50. in
bank--sent for Press Bureau--
Got bonnet at H. Backens
don't like it yet--
Man put down plain
white straw matting all around
front chamber--& put the Julia
Foster blue & red [way?] up there--
it has always been on the living
room floor--it is beautiful--
At last the attick stir--my
has been sorted over--and
papers, pamphlets &c put together
ready for sorting--saving & destroying
Annie Davis sister Jennie
here helping clean house--her
[mistress?] Miss Aldridge gone [?]
Miss Shaw & niece
Lucy E. to start for their
Cape Cod summer home to-day.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her day, including going down town, putting money in the bank, getting a bonnet, and having work done on her house. She also mentions people who are helping her clean and pack for the summer.

entries.fullText:
Pleasant day--
Mr. Gannett's question was
Is the manly woman less womanly
or the womanly man less manly?
a very nicely drawn statement
of the new woman--& new
man--both the product of
higher civilization
Stopped to his class--
Theodore Parker the
subject--
A most
surprising letter--to B.C.
from Mrs. Catt--showing
under the ink & between the
lines dissatisfaction pitiful!!
with Mrs Foster Avery--Lucy E. & my own
management of the Wash. Con.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about attending a class and hearing a question about gender roles. She also mentions a letter from Mrs. Catt expressing dissatisfaction with the management of the Washington Convention.

entries.fullText: Wea. Wed. May 18, 1898. Ther.

William Ewart Gladstone
England's Grand Old Man"-
passed on to the beyond at
5 this A.M. at the age
of he died at
his home Hawarden Castle
entries.summaryText: William Ewart Gladstone passed away at his home, Hawarden Castle, at the age of

entries.dateText:
Waim &
Thomas
Wea. Sun. May 22, 1898. Ther.
entries.fullText:
Mr. Garnetts text
Gladstone--England's
Grand Old man--
Made him the Campion
of Emancipation--&
enlarging--extending the
suffrage--was perfectly
oblivious to the sad fact
that for one half of England's
subjects--he set his face
against their enfranchisement--
though a petition of nearly a
half-million asked it of
Parliament--the great
Liberal Commoner went
out with the opposition--
granting all that he was
for English & Irish men--he
was a liberal on the woman
question--
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about Mr. Garnett's text and Gladstone's stance on suffrage.

entries.fullText: Wea. TUES. MAY 24, 1898 Ther.
Wea. WED. MAY 25, 1898 Ther.
Wea. THUR. MAY 26, 1898 Ther.
Wea. FRI. MAY 27, 1898 Ther.
At home -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote about being at home on May 30, 1898.

entries.fullText: At home - and J. P. M. went Reynold's [Lik] [?] - to Daughters to American Revolution [?] meeting - for trained nurses to volunteer to go to the [port?] - 15 did so - Ms. Montgomery spoke also - she had great faculty to think of things to say -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote about being at home on May 31, 1898 and attending a meeting for trained nurses to volunteer to go to a port. Ms. Montgomery spoke at the meeting and 15 nurses volunteered.

entries.fullText:
at home
Went to Mrs Fuilam’s
To try on new waist lining to the
grenadine I got in San Francisco
two years ago - Then went down
Sophia St - to old man
Twaits about making shoes
that wouldn’t crush my toes
down - all in a bunch - at
the end of my shoes - on
account of new paving between
Canal bridge & Fitzburgh street -
had to walk a great deal
- & all the way from Jones
Street home - & it did seem
as I must give up the job
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about trying on a new waist lining and getting shoes that wouldn't crush her toes due to new paving.

entries.fullText:
At home
Went to Mrs Fullams
to try on grenadine waist
& found she had to buy new
outside as well as lining-
Had to dinner with
us - Mrs Elizabeth Lowe Watson
& daughter Lucretia - and
Mrs L.C. Smith & daughter
Mrs Tanner - also Mrs Emma
B. Sweet - expected Mrs -
Greenleaf - but she failed -
had a very pleasant visit
at 8 went to Mrs
Amelia Logan’s - to see her
mother Sarah Anthony [Demitrius?] -
soon to be 87 - took tea - &
then went to 1st M.E. Church
to colored M.E. Conference
for western New York - Bishop
Walker & others spoke - I
made short talk at [?end?] -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about trying on a new waist and having dinner with several guests. She also visits Mrs. Amelia Logan and attends a conference at 1st M.E. Church.

entries.fullText:
Pleasant - at home
letter from Mrs. Harper
says she will come here
next Wednesday - to begin
reading & cutting down the
copy for Biography -
entries.summaryText: Received a letter from Mrs. Harper who will come next Wednesday to work on the Biography.

entries.fullText:
At home worked
on chapters with Miss
Hawley studying where
to cut out -
At evening sister
May & self went to
Zions Church Favor St
to Literary exercises - bright
speeches - recitations - music
For the five days of the
Conference the colored
women have cooked
& served dinners for
80 & 100 - in the church
basement - & this evening
after 11 oclock they served
ice cream & cake -
entries.summaryText: Worked on chapters with Miss Hawley and attended Literary exercises at Zions Church. Colored women served dinners and ice cream during the Conference.

entries.fullText:
Went to church -
to my chagrin found
that Mrs. Gannetts father
& mother had gone
home yesterday - and I
not ever called on them
This evening Sister Mary &
self went to the Colored
M.E. Zions Conference held
in the 1st M. church - white -
Bishop Alexander Walters
took up collection - it
was good as a show.
wished Mrs. Catt & Miss Hay
could have been there to see &
learn how to do it - got
57 dollars - out of colored people
making $100 for the [?] meeting this day
entries.summaryText: Went to church and then to the Colored M.E. Zions Conference held in the 1st M. church. Bishop Alexander Walters took up collection. Got 57 dollars - out of colored people making $100 for the [?] meeting this day.

entries.fullText:
Woman's Christian
Association to dedicate
its new building this P.M.
at 3. oclock & I
went over to north Clinton
Street - a large crowd of women
& told them true philosophy
was to remove the cause
of the damages - which
they were seeking to repair
At evening went to
Ancammon Hall - south
St Paul St - to closing
reception of the African
M.E. Zion's Western New York
Conference - really wonderful
specimens of progress for
thirty years of half a chance
Went this A.M. to
last try-on of the
grenadine - which Mrs.
Fullam has made over
with new waist entire
entries.summaryText: Went to the Woman's Christian Association to dedicate its new building and then to the closing reception of the African M.E. Zion's Western New York Conference. Went this A.M. to last try-on of the grenadine - which Mrs. Fullam has made over with new waist entire.

entries.fullText: [*Promised to speak at the dedication of [?N?] Woman’s Christian Associations men’s meeting this P.M. at. 2nd O. and this was for [??]*] - at home - reading on Geography chapters with Miss Hawley
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony promised to speak at the dedication of a Women's Christian Association. She spent the day at home reading Geography chapters with Miss Hawley.

entries.fullText: at home reading chapters - This evg walked over to Mrs Hallowells
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spent the day at home reading chapters and in the evening walked over to Mrs. Hallowell's.

entries.fullText:
Worked all day and finished reading
21-- just one-half
of the chapters--
got second package
of them back from the
Bowen Merrill Co - and
found their suggestions
for cutting out agreed
with mine.

Mrs Harper and her
Winnifred arrived at 9.10
from Washington D.C.
after seven weeks absence.

Now for the cutting
down of the 500,000
words to as nearly 400,000
as may be -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony worked on editing a manuscript and received feedback from Bowen Merrill Co. Mrs. Harper and Winnifred arrived from Washington D.C. after seven weeks absence.

entries.fullText:
-
-Mrs. Harper and Winifred
downtown in P.M.-
-nice talk over the
condition of affairs-
the book in particular
Sister May finished
a sock out of old
spotted black silk-
very nice & cool
made an old silk lining
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Harper, Winifred, and Sister May had a nice talk over the condition of affairs, the book in particular. Sister May finished a sock out of old spotted black silk and made an old silk lining.

entries.fullText: at home
entries.summaryText: At home.

entries.fullText:
at home
Mrs Harper & self commenced reading
Chap. I - of [Beagrofly?]
this morning - & [drizzled?]
over & on five weeks
at [?21’] continually -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony and Mrs. Harper read Chapter I of Beagrofly at home.

entries.fullText:
at home - working
on Cart cut down of
[co?] for [??] & work of S.B.A.
Letter from Mr
Elisha W. McGuire - att.
16 Exchange Place - New York City
informs me that our dear
old friend Miss
Arathusa L. Forbes - of
St. Louis Mo- & lately of Jersey
City- N. Jersey - died at the
Bloomingdales Assylum - this
eveg - she always gave
to help the cause to extent of
her ability - was a trusted friend
of dear Mrs N.L. [Niman?] and
true to Phoebe [?Cougins?] always
-her mind failed several
years ago -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony receives a letter from Mr. Elisha W. McGuire informing her of the death of Miss Arathusa L. Forbes, a trusted friend and supporter of the cause, who had recently been living in Jersey City and had always given to the cause to the extent of her ability.

entries.fullText: at home
entries.summaryText: Journal entry from June 19, 1898

entries.fullText: at home
entries.summaryText: Journal entry from June 20, 1898

entries.fullText:
POSTMASTER APPOINTED
Leavenworth Times
PRESIDENT NOMINATES D.R. AN-
THONY, JR.; FOR LEAVEN-
WORTH POST OFFICE 1898
Washington, D.C., June 20.-The
president today sent the name of Dan-
iel R. Anthony Jr., to the senate for
postmaster at Leavenworth Kan.
entries.summaryText: Journal entry from June 20, 1898 about the appointment of Daniel R. Anthony Jr. as postmaster at Leavenworth Kan.

entries.fullText:
working till 4 - on cutting
down chapters - then
tried to sleep - at
7.30 started for meeting
at Chamber of
Commerce Room —
to consider opening the
Rochester University
to girls - saving the
$100,000 - for the
[??]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony worked on cutting down chapters and attended a meeting at the Chamber of Commerce Room to discuss opening Rochester University to girls.

entries.fullText:
Read chapters
XXI & XXII - this day - the
weather warm again
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony read chapters XXI & XXII and noted that the weather was warm again.

entries.fullText:
Ther.
at home
All these
days working,
over Manuscript
cutt' out-__
cutt' down

Winifred left
for Mayville -
Photograph Co - to
print her and
to usher them
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was at home working on her manuscript and Winifred left for Mayville to print her photographs.

entries.fullText:
Ther.
at home
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was at home.

entries.fullText:
finished two chapters this
P. No. 25 and 26- - So we
have 24 left- to the read
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony finished reading two chapters.

entries.fullText:
a letter from Mrs.
Helen B. Pillsbury Cogswell -
Governor - _. ____
Written [june] this 26th
- days that for the last two
Weeks her dear father
Parker Pillsbury- has been
very ill - a Mill confirmed so
that there was little hope of his
recovery
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony received a letter from Mrs. Helen B. Pillsbury Cogswell about her father's illness.

entries.fullText:
Mrs. Fullam's - 21 [?] St
this May - had fitted grey
nuns [?] dress - it
must be queer to have anything
but black - but it would
be a change
Miss Sanders - sister
of Gov & Ex. U.S. Senator
Sanders of Montana
called this A.M.
At evening called on
Mrs. Montgomery - Lawyer
Davis had made the
Pledge leading for Co
Ed. Fund much stronger
-then called at Dr.
Sherman Ricker's for Mrs.
Harper - who is suffering
greatly with exema - or salt
rheum - the old fashion - on
her right ear
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Fullam's fitting, Miss Sanders visit, Mrs. Montgomery's visit, and Mrs. Harper's suffering.

entries.fullText:
At home
Mrs. Harper went to Dr.
Sanford to get her bridge
re-set on tooth that
has been under treatment
the past two weeks -
wrote brother D.R. - also
replied to H.B.U. who
wrote me I was fault-finding
with all the girls!! I
wrote her of my [?] had been
[?] - my spirit surely
had not
forgot to go to the
Central Church - to Free
Academy Commencement exercises
this forenoon - but Principal
Allen called for me
I have promised to go & tell
the girls my wish to see
all who thought themselves
ready to enter the university
The Alexander [?] {?]
at Salsburgs [?]
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Harper's dental appointment, correspondence with family and friends, and attending Free Academy Commencement exercises.

entries.fullText:
The Santiago siege
began this A.M. with
most terrible results.
Rained there yesterday
poured strait down - So
the poor men were
knee deep in mud
to make their way to fight
It is an awful war -
-the death dealing
inventions should make
this their very last of
the wicked barbarism

[Following is news clipping]
Deaths
KIMBALL- At National City July 1, 1898,
Flora M., wife of Warren C. Kimball,
aged 69 years, a native of Newhampshire.
Friends are invited to attend the funeral
services at the residence in National City
at 2:30 p.m. today. [Following in SBA's hand] Sunday July 3/98
entries.summaryText: The Santiago siege began with terrible results due to the rain and mud. SBA comments on the barbarism of war and includes a news clipping about a death in National City.

entries.fullText:
[*Clear & hot*]
Wea. Sat. July 2, 1898 Ther. - 95
At home
Winnifred Harper
returned on Empire
State - from Mayville - with
fearful cold & general break up
We have now sunken
on the serious going over
the copy to cut-down & out -
just three weeks - have gotten
through 36 of the chapters
but the cuttings are small-
--------------
Second day of the
awful mowing-down
of human-beings at
Santiago de Cuba - Gen
Shafter at head of one [?]
weighing 210 lbs
entries.summaryText: SBA notes the weather and that Winnifred Harper has returned home. She also mentions working on cutting down a copy and comments on the ongoing war in Santiago de Cuba.

entries.fullText:
At home
did not go to church
Mr. Flora Ms. Riviball
of Berchal for - fal
wife of the maner I. Riviball
was luner Mrs. P. Ms - she
died July 1st quiz - the
my day soul therafter was
moving into dinner at Iantago
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about spending the day at home and mentions several people and locations.

entries.fullText: At home
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was at home on July 5, 1898.

entries.fullText: The 53rd Teachers Con in session - Sister May & self went to Central Church to hear Charles E. Fitch on Patriotism & Education. He gave Note Supt Skinner credit for flags on school houses!!
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attended the 53rd Teachers Con and went to Central Church to hear Charles E. Fitch speak on Patriotism & Education. Fitch gave credit to Supt Skinner for flags on school houses.

entries.fullText:
At home
at 2.30 - Went to the
Lake - with Miss Nate
Stoneman - of Albany -
with the 1,000 teachers
from all parts of the state -
in their 53d state Con - it
is just 45 years since
I invaded their Con. in
old Corinthian Hall -
when Prof. James was Pres -
- They have elected Prof -
Noyes Pres. for coming year -
Parker Pillsbury died at
noon this noon - July. 7, 1898
was born Sept. 22, 1809
_________________
10 - 15 days - 88 yrs
That is he was
88 yrs - 10 months & 15 days old -
almost 89 - he was therefore
about 10 years older than I - adoption month
[*was 13 years a loss*]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about attending a state convention in Albany and the death of Parker Pillsbury.

entries.fullText:
At home
Telegram - at noon -
from Mrs Helen B.
Pillsbury Cogswell - says
"Father Passed away yesterday
Funeral - Monday at twelve" -
- So at 88 almost 89 [Mistress]
Parker Pillsbury follows
Robert Purvis - Samuel
May Jr. is now the only one
of the old Ex. Com. of the
Honey & A.S. Committee of
Boston - It does seem too
bad for me not to go on to
Concord - to be with lone girl
Helen - first her uncle, then her
husband, then her mother & now
in a few months - her father - & she
left in the house all alone!!
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony receives a telegram about the death of Parker Pillsbury and expresses concern for his daughter Helen.

entries.fullText: At home
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote a brief entry stating that she was at home.

entries.fullText:
At home
Mrs Hair had an
interview in Dem &
Chron. this A.M.
that stirred up the
men teachers - for
not recognizing women
any more than that
of 45 years ago - when
I made them [?] speech,
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote about Mrs. Hair's interview in Dem & Chron that stirred up the men teachers for not recognizing women any more than they did 45 years ago.

entries.fullText:
The funeral of Parker Pillsbury his foreman-William LLoyd Jamison Jr. & brother Frank attended wake gave an address mentioning his royal father & mother & P.P’s life & work-

I Had to stay at home for this wake- as I had to stay away from Phila - where my lain mother stay

Robert Purnis- P.P. Mas left 22.1809
entries.summaryText: Attended Parker Pillsbury's funeral and stayed home for the wake.

entries.fullText: At home
entries.summaryText: At home

entries.fullText: At home
entries.summaryText: At home

entries.fullText:
Mrs. Harper doing up
last must-be's on the
book & pushing to
be off tomorrow - she
is very tired & nervous
in head & mind
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Harper is finishing up work and is tired and nervous.

entries.fullText:
Mrs. Harper & Winnifred
left for Chautauqua
at 11 A.M. - after
five more weeks of close
& trying work - cutting
out over 40,000 words
from the Biography chapters
- Winnifred here over three weeks
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Harper and Winnifred leave for Chautauqua after weeks of work on the biography.

entries.fullText:
trying to settle
into some sort
of work - but all
[?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about trying to settle into work at home.

entries.fullText:
trying to settle
into some sort
of work - but all
[?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about trying to settle into work at home.

entries.fullText:
all the day - awfully
oppressive - with lowering
clouds but little rain.
Sister May - tea at
Mrs. Greenleafs -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends the day at home with oppressive weather and has tea with Sister May at Mrs. Greenleafs.

entries.fullText:
Mrs. C.C. Catt - at Chautauqua
by invitation - Geo. H. Vincent
Letter from The
Bowen Merrill Co. this
A.M. containing $250.
Check - their first payment
of advance royalty on
Life & Work of S.B.A. -
of course Mrs. Harper gets
her check - the same - as
our contract gives her half -
Corner stone of F.
Douglas Monument laid
this P.M. at 4 o'clock.
A postcard from
H. B.Blackwell saying Mrs.
Stanton's article on P.P. too late -
we published last week our
In Memoriam article comprised
mainly of Wm. Lloyd Garrison's address
at the funeral.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony receives a check from The Bowen Merrill Co. for the advance royalty on Life & Work of S.B.A. and attends the laying of the corner stone of F. Douglas Monument. She also receives a postcard from H. B.Blackwell regarding Mrs. Stanton's article on P.P. which was published last week in the In Memoriam article comprised mainly of Wm. Lloyd Garrison's address at the funeral.

entries.fullText: At home
entries.summaryText: At home

entries.fullText: At home
entries.summaryText: At home

entries.fullText:
Mrs. Marjorie J. Tommy
of S. C & husband came
at 11:30 - in midst of
a slight shower - but
it did not cool off
the air -

The Mar - San
Juan horrors fill every
ones thoughts -
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Marjorie J. Tommy of S. C & husband came at 11:30 - in midst of a slight shower - but it did not cool off the air - The Mar - San Juan horrors fill every ones thoughts -

entries.fullText:
Hot -
Marjorie J. Tommy - Pres of
South Carolina W.S.A
and her doctor - husband
here. I went with them
to driving Park bridge to see
the lower falls - then
back & across Platt. [?]
bridge to see the upper
falls - day very hot -
Mrs. May B. Ferguson of
Newburg & of Halls Corners
called - The Jon[?]
left at 4 to take the
Lake steamer for Montreal -
entries.summaryText: Marjorie J. Tommy - Pres of South Carolina W.S.A and her doctor - husband here. I went with them to driving Park bridge to see the lower falls - then back & across Platt. [?] bridge to see the upper falls - day very hot - Mrs. May B. Ferguson of Newburg & of Halls Corners called - The Jon[?] left at 4 to take the Lake steamer for Montreal -

entries.fullText: at home
entries.summaryText: Journal entry on July 27, 1898, at home.

entries.fullText:
at home -
a most remarkable letter
from L. H. H. written the 26th.
entries.summaryText: Journal entry on July 28, 1898, at home. Mentions a remarkable letter from L. H. H. written on the 26th.

entries.fullText:
at home
a year ago today -
mother Ramiel & movement,
writer May and Sally -smither &
great May cousins Harley
at dear old Adams-
when - I am read '
her roof of her fathering
Hannah- every day-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about being at home and reminiscing about a year ago when she was with family and friends in Adams.

entries.fullText: At home
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes that she is at home.

entries.fullText:
Sister May & self
went to Unitarian Church
newly fitted up parlor - &
saw & heard my former sec'y
read Mrs. Stanton's Solitude of
Self - & Olive Schreiner's dream
of "Heaven on Earth" - she
read well & appeared well
& I was very proud of her -
Emma Biddlum [?]
At evening we called
at Sarah Willis & Mary
Hallowell's - & on
return at 9 found Uncle
John Anthony's grandson
Samuel W. Anthony sitting
on the steps - he had been
at the Lake during the day
& stopped over night with us
to attend to some business
at Bank Monday
entries.summaryText: Attended Unitarian Church and heard former secretary read works by Mrs. Stanton and Olive Schreiner. Visited Sarah Willis and Mary Hallowell in the evening and had a surprise visit from Samuel W. Anthony.

entries.fullText: At home
entries.summaryText: At home.

entries.fullText:
At home.
Letter from Sigrida E.
Magnusson of Iceland -
whom I met at the Chicago
Exposition of 1892 - writes from
Emily Howland's- Sherwood
that she will be here to-day
& Maud Gage Baum
writes that she has shipped a
box of her mother's - M. J. Gages-
letters & papers to me by freight
from Fayetteville.
Mrs. Magnusson came on 2 P.M. train
I took her to Driving Park Bridge to
see Lower Falls - & to Platt. for Upper
Falls.
entries.summaryText: Received a letter from Sigrida Magnusson and Maud Gage Baum, and spent time with Magnusson visiting various locations.

entries.fullText:
At home
Madam
Magnusson of Iceland left at
10:00 for Niagara Falls.
A large roll of proof came
from B.M. & Co. - read & mailed
galleys to Mrs. Harper at noon
- & at night mailed to
B.M. & Co. the large proof with
a few blunders - for Mrs. H,
might discover all -
A good letter from
dear Mrs. Southweather with
her $500 for Press Bureau-
this makes $1406 - in all - Mrs
S. thinks [?] for organizations
gone by - am glad she believes
in educational work through
the press - she is a very
generous woman -
entries.summaryText: Received a letter from Mrs. Southweather with a donation for the Press Bureau and sent proofs to Mrs. Harper and B.M. & Co. Madam Magnusson left for Niagara Falls.

entries.fullText:
At home
reading proof all
the forenoon.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony reads proof at home all morning.

entries.fullText:
At home
Worked all the forenoon
reading proof - and
P.M. dictating & writing
ten letters also -
Weather cool.
Santiago solders
suffering sadly & many of them
from the dreadful climate
lack of all sanitary
[?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony works from home in the morning, writes letters in the afternoon, and notes the suffering of soldiers in Santiago due to poor conditions.

entries.fullText:
First galley proof today
ended the XXXVIII chapter
the proof is [?] free
from blunders -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony worked on the galley proof for chapter 38 at home.

entries.fullText:
Some Sunday along
here either earlier or later
Dr. Henry Barrows - the
President of the Parliament
of religions - World Fair - 1893 -
preached morning and evening at
the Unit. Church - he came
down and spoke to me after
the sermon. I told him it was
a good & [following word underlined] quaker sermon as
I wanted - in the evening it was
more doctrinal- I asked him to
come to tea - Monday evening - I
invited Mrs. Montgomery, & Mrs.
Sanford - talked on woman suffrage
Said he was strong for it in his young
days- he wrote his high school upon it
and his Latin essay at college - but
he married a woman who didn't believe
in it - and so he dropped it -
In the course of conversation
he said - Miss Anthony do you
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends a sermon by Dr. Henry Barrows and invites him to tea to discuss woman suffrage.

entries.fullText:
Miss Belle Kearney
of Mississippi - to call
here from 2:20 to 4:20 train
Your Movement waits its
success for the coming of
the church women - and
I said yes that is what I have
always seen & felt - but -
Mr. Barrow & his church women
wait for the preaching of the
like of you! Do you think so -
said her - most surely - said
he - when the ministers there
to preach suffrage - the members
will flock to our suffrage
meeting &c
entries.summaryText: Miss Belle Kearney from Mississippi visited and discussed the suffrage movement with Susan B. Anthony and Mr. Barrow.

people: Mr. John M. & Mrs. A.D. Thayer
entries.fullText:
Golden wedding of
Mr. John M. & Mrs. A.D. Thayer -
the parents of May T. Sanford -
this evening - Sister Anna O. [Aulty?]
went with us -
entries.summaryText: Attended the golden wedding of Mr. John M. & Mrs. A.D. Thayer, parents of May T. Sanford, with Sister Anna O. [Aulty?]

entries.fullText: Sister Annie with us
entries.summaryText: Sister Annie was with us

entries.fullText:
At home -
Mrs. L.L. Blankenships father
& Dr. Hannah Myers Longshore
husband Edward Longshore
died this day at 86 years of age
had his mental faculties until
the very last - was ill only 16 days.
Sister Anna O. here
with us -
entries.summaryText: Mrs. L.L. Blankenships father & Dr. Hannah Myers Longshore's husband Edward Longshore died at home. Sister Anna O. was with them.

entries.fullText:
Sister Anna too the 9:05 train
this A.M. for New York
where [?] loves [?]
& her darling married niece to
meet her at the Waldorf
Astoria.
entries.summaryText: Sister Anna took the train to New York to meet her niece at the Waldorf Astoria.

entries.fullText: Wrote letters until noon - in P.M. went with Miss Besel to see Dr. Sherman Riker & then to Mrs. Montgomerys - to talk best course for this girl to get medical education - & after it had a nice talk with Mrs. M - on her work
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about writing letters and visiting Dr. Sherman Riker and Mrs. Montgomerys to discuss a girl's medical education.

entries.fullText: A letter from George E. Vincent - inviting me to speak at Chautauqua next year.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony receives a letter from George E. Vincent inviting her to speak at Chautauqua next year.

entries.fullText:
read 9 galleys of
proof that came Sunday
noon & mailed to Mrs.
Harper. - a telegram
from B.M. & Co asking for the
galley proof of Chapter XXXIV
- it failed between Mrs. Harper
& [?] - for she had sent my
copy back to me - & I sent it
on to [?] B.M. & Co. -
A letter from Dr.
John Henry Randrus - today
from Mackinaw Island - tells
of receipt of the set of History
saying he would read thoroughly
and report to me - I sent him
my Life & the History.
entries.summaryText: Received a telegram from B.M. & Co asking for the galley proof of Chapter XXXIV. A letter from Dr. John Henry Randrus from Mackinaw Island tells of receipt of the set of History.

entries.fullText:
Reading - or listening to
Miss Bailey's reading of
chapters the proof of which
will come while I am away.
entries.summaryText: Listening to Miss Bailey's reading of chapters the proof of which will come while I am away.

entries.fullText:
Took train with sister May
at 11.45 in pouring rain
from Cayuga Bridge. & thence by
steamer to Aurora at 4.20
found Isabel and Phebe Fort at
wharf also Aunt Emily's carriage
- thence we drove 4 miles
directly east to Sherwood
Emily Howland's lovely old
Home - fully 8 year old [?]
found a hearty welcome
It was my first visit to
Sherwood since 1850s - then I
fell into Orthodox Beaty's
hands so didn't meet the
Howland's - at least none
of them remember me or I them
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Sherwood and Emily Howland's home for the first time since the 1850s.

entries.fullText:
Dined at Isabels father & mothers
Slocum & Hannah Letchworth
Howlands - & then drove
4 miles southeast to
Venice Center Grove - the
Farmers Festival - fully a
1,000 people there - for a
grand dance on the
beautiful floor under the
trees - on which the 1,000
stood - [??late] I spok a
half-hour - & then they
resumed their dancing &
chatting as they pleased
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends the Farmers Festival at Venice Center Grove and gives a speech.

entries.fullText:
The man Benjamin
Brewster drove us back
to Aurora - & out to see
the Wells College buildings -
& we took the 11.45 boat
a beautiful almost cold
day - reached Cayuga just
to catch train - Sister
May stopped off at
Geneva - to see Cousin
Lucius Howe & his two
girls - Nettie & Nina - the
father has been an invalid
for many years - I reached
home at 4.20 & found Mrs Harper
had arrived, yesterday and
sister Mary arrived at 8.40
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Aurora and Cayuga, and visits Cousin Lucius Howe and his daughters Nettie and Nina in Geneva.

entries.fullText:
At Home -
and the proof has
just piled in upon us
The first instalment
of Plate proof here this A.M.
To my surprise - since they
wrote me they would not
begin stereotyping until all
was in page proof - & we
had gone over it just as they
had it ready to stereotype
Niece Anna O. - brother
Merritts daughter came at
9 Oclock from Chautauqua
looking well & feeling splendidly
that her six weeks at that
assembly had done her good
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony receives plate proof and her niece Anna O. visits from Chautauqua.

entries.fullText:
At home
Sister Mary and niece Anna O.
went to 3rd Presbyterian Church
East Av & Meiggs Street - heard
Rev Sewell -Mr. Bacon
called on niece Anne O.
at evening took long walk
with Mrs Harper
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends the day at home with her sister and niece, attends church, and takes a walk with Mrs. Harper.

entries.fullText:
At home
went down to Lawyers
Cooperative Publishing House
Cox Building to find our
Indexer for Biography
Mrs Thomas Rames called
& invited me to speak for their
Tuesday Afternoon club
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends the day at home and goes to the Lawyers Cooperative Publishing House to find an indexer for her biography. She is also invited to speak at the Tuesday Afternoon club by Mrs. Thomas Rames.

entries.fullText: At home
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was at home.

entries.fullText:
At home
Niece Anna O. Anthony
here -- a telegram from
nephew Daniel R Anthony Jr -
saying his little wife --
"Bessie requests me to
notify Aunt Susan of the
arrival of a daughter at
our house this morning all
doing well" -- to which I
replied -- "Heartiest greetings
to father mother and
daughter from great
Aunts Mary and
Susan B Anthony-
this is brother Dan's first grand
child -- also the first of
Bessie's father, and mother -- it is
the first child of the youngest
child of both families --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony received a telegram from her nephew Daniel R Anthony Jr announcing the birth of his daughter. Susan replied with greetings from her and her sister Mary.

entries.fullText: at home --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was at home on September 1, 1898.

entries.fullText:
at home
went to Dr. Regina --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was at home on September 2, 1898 and went to see Dr. Regina.

entries.fullText:
At home --
reading proof - galley -
of [Phap?] XLV - 45 - of Aug -

It does begin to seem
like nearing the end --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is at home reading proof and feels like it's nearing the end.

entries.fullText:
At home --
Niece Anna O. [Anthony?]
went to church with me
it is Mr. [Garmatts?] first
Sunday after his six weeks
vacation -- awfully hot -- and
very [hey feur?] there --
Mrs G not home yet --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is at home with her niece Anna O. [Anthony?] and they went to church together. It is Mr. [Garmatts?] first Sunday after his six weeks vacation. It is hot and very [hey feur?] there. Mrs. G is not home yet.

entries.fullText:
At home -
went to Dr Requa's in
A. M. - can't decide how
to fix my plate
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is at home and goes to Dr. Requa's in the morning. She is undecided about how to fix her plate.

people: ladies of the G. A. R.
entries.fullText:
At home -
The national - 25th G. A. R.
encampment at Cincinnati O.
opens to day - also the
ladies of the G. A. R. and the
W. R. C. women - at same place -
and I have not written to
any of them - begging them
to declare strongly for woman
suffrage -
I was seized
with bowels running off -
& kept it up all night
every 15 or 20 minutes -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is at home and mentions the national 25th G.A.R. encampment in Cincinnati, Ohio. She regrets not having written to the ladies of the G.A.R. and the W.R.C. women to ask for their support for woman suffrage. She also mentions being ill with bowel issues throughout the night.

entries.fullText: Sister May went over to [?] and telephoned Dr. Sherman-Dicken to call - - a queer flatness - no fever - no nothing - but goal for nothing.
entries.summaryText: Sister May called Dr. Sherman-Dicken for a queer flatness with no fever.

entries.fullText: At home and in bed - [?] came this A.M.--
entries.summaryText: At home and in bed, someone came in the morning.

entries.fullText:
under the weather
with something wrong --
taking only gruel
Sister Mary & niece
Anna O. went to
church - the latter
delighted with Mr
Gannetts sermon
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is feeling unwell and only having gruel. Her sister Mary and niece Anna O. went to church and Anna enjoyed Mr. Gannett's sermon.

entries.fullText:
at home
The Doctor made her
last call this A.M.
Niece Anna O.
took Northern Central
R.R. train at 6:45 A.M.
for Phila -- she had been
with us two weeks - has
improved greatly every
way with her four
years in Philadelphia
& Drexel --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is at home and her niece Anna O. leaves for Philadelphia after staying with them for two weeks and improving greatly in every way.

entries.fullText: Had on dress today again - but Richard is far from herself yet
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote about wearing a dress and Richard not feeling well.

entries.fullText: Celebration of the Frederick Douglass Monument in Fitzhugh Hall 2 P.M. The founders failed to deliver the monument so there were no unveiling ceremonies in the forenoon Mrs. Ida B. Wells of Chicago arrived.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attended a celebration for the Frederick Douglass Monument and Mrs. Ida B. Wells arrived from Chicago.

entries.fullText:
The "Afro-American
Council" - Met in Common
Council Chamber - both morning
& afternoon - Bishop Walters,
Pres - Mrs Wells-Barnett Sec'y - &
J. W. Thompson Treasurer -.
In evening Mrs Helen Pitts
Douglass took tea with us -
& a large number of colored
women called -. Also the
ex-minister of Iberia - Mr Smyth -
-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about attending a meeting of the Afro-American Council and having tea with Mrs. Helen Pitts Douglass and a group of colored women. She also mentions meeting Mr. Smyth, the ex-minister of Iberia.

entries.fullText:
Rosa Douglass Sprague
called for an hour - then
went with Mrs. Wells-Barnett
to dinner at - [Mrs Greenleafs]
Rev & Mrs Gannetts - & after
that to Mt Hope - where
it seems Mrs Potts Douglass
has placed a massive
granite slab - over the
grave - & the sons Lewis
& Charles a slab at head
of Frederick Douglass - Thus
leaving out the only daughter
Rosa - altogether - &
Mrs. Potts-D. proposes now to
remove the remains to
Anacostia - Cedar - Hill -
- get a bill though Congress
charting the place - & The Frederick
Douglass memorial & historical
Association - erect a monument
there - & make it a
mecca for colored people
to visit!!
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about Rosa Douglass Sprague visiting her and then going to dinner with Mrs. Wells-Barnett. She also mentions Mrs. Potts Douglass's plans to remove Frederick Douglass's remains to Anacostia and erect a monument there.

entries.fullText: Went over to Mrs. Fullam's both forenoon & afternoon & forgot then that I wanted to have her try on & finish my garnet colored red silk tea gown so as to take it with me to Maine. Telling anyway but right, somehow do not get back any life or action or spirit for anything.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Mrs. Fullam and forgets to have her try on and finish her garnet colored red silk tea gown.

entries.fullText: Sister May went to church - Mrs. W. [Barnett?] with her then Mrs. B. went to Mrs. Greenleaf's to dinner - got into a controversy with their visitor Mr. Smith of Norton who contended Washington never held slaves - Mrs. Greenleaf brought out the Cyclopedia & found he left 100 - at his death !!
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony's sister and Mrs. W. [Barnett?] go to church while Susan B. Anthony stays at home. Later, she attends a dinner at Mrs. Greenleaf's where a controversy arises with their visitor Mr. Smith of Norton over whether or not Washington held slaves.

entries.fullText:
At home
Went to see Mrs Montgomery
about University Fund
meetings - & she will set
about arranging to make
the week from Oct 6. to 10 -
solid with parlor & public
meetings - with Miss Shaw
to speak with her -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony went to see Mrs. Montgomery about University Fund meetings and arranging for a week of parlor and public meetings with Miss Shaw.

entries.fullText:
At home
Doing next to nothing
- took walk after
dinner. Then to
Dr Sherman Rickers
- found her gone
out driving - then
went to Mr & Mrs
Gannetts took tea,
& spent evening &
got home at 10.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spent the day at home, took a walk, visited Dr. Sherman Rickers, and had tea with Mr. and Mrs. Gannett.

entries.fullText: Note from Mrs Montgomery - that she couldn't get Mrs Lockman & so no call sent out for Co. Ed. meeting - at Watson House to - day - Dr. Sherm Rickers called this A. M. - so much feeling of nausea & so sluggish all round
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Montgomery couldn't get Mrs. Lockman for Co. Ed. meeting at Watson House. Dr. Sherm Rickers called in the morning.

entries.fullText: Left home - at 5:45 Sister May in Carriage - Train - 20 minutes late - So left at 6:35 - not 6:15, - The clouds not lifted - though it is good to be whirling on the cars Reached North Adams about 2 P.M. found Mr H. Torrey Cady & wife Harriet Cook Cady - gone to the train - - so the girl - Maggie - let me in & showed me to room - where I went to bed - & slept till five - & when dressed & went down found Hattie waiting on porch - for some one to unlock the screen door - had a warm welcome & decided to spend tomorrow & she would drive me down to Cheshire
