entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left home and arrived in North Adams. She found Mr. H. Torrey Cady and wife Harriet Cook Cady gone. She spent the night and decided to spend the next day with Hattie and drive to Cheshire.

entries.fullText:
- the rain fell all the
forenoon - so gave up
the drive to Cheshire to
see cousin, Esther - the
only surviving child of
mother's cousin Ira Richardson -
& wife Anna Jenks __
- But in P.M. Mr. Cady took
me a drive over the hills
of the non city of North Adams
- the sun warm & bright -
- in evening many called -.
Uncle Humphrey's William
called - seemed in good
heart - is living in N. Adams -
- the home farm is rented
to a stranger
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spent the day at the Cadys, gave up the drive to Cheshire to see cousin Esther due to rain, but took a drive over the hills of North Adams with Mr. Cady. Uncle Humphrey's William called in the evening.

entries.fullText:
Mr Cady took me to
station for 7.20 train -
- the rain poured all day -
- as we entered the
tunnel - & as we whirled
down the Deerfield River -
- the loveliest valley
imaginable - reached
Boston at 1 - and at. 1.15
was on B. & M. train for
Portland - reached there
at 5 - P.M. found Mrs
Galen Foster at station - Who
escorted me to the old
quaint home of George
& Charlotte J. Thomas -
145- Street - Portland
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony took a train from Boston to Portland, where she was escorted to the home of George and Charlotte J. Thomas by Mrs. Galen Foster.

entries.fullText: in Portland
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was in Portland on September 25, 1898.

entries.fullText: guest of Miss Charlotte J. Thomas-145-Danforth Street - the President of Club is Mrs Lucy Hobart-Day 283. Brackett Street - Portland
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was a guest of Miss Charlotte J. Thomas in Portland-Maine on September 26, 1898. She also mentions the President of Club, Mrs Lucy Hobart-Day, and provides their address.

entries.fullText:
State Annual Convention
guest of my dear old
Riggs House Wash.D.C.
friend & hostess Mrs
Jane H. Spofford
Miss Thomas staffer
at Mrs Spoffords was
a splendid meeting
in the town Hall
entries.summaryText: Attended State Annual Convention in Hampden Corners Maine and stayed with Mrs. Jane H. Spofford in Wash.D.C. Miss Thomas was also present. The meeting was held at Mrs. Spofford's and was splendid.

entries.fullText:
Maine State Annual
Suffrage Convention
entries.summaryText: Attended Maine State Annual Suffrage Convention.

entries.fullText: In Hampden
entries.summaryText: Short journal entry stating that Susan B. Anthony was in Hampden on September 29, 1898.

entries.fullText: In Hampden
entries.summaryText: Short journal entry stating that Susan B. Anthony was in Hampden on September 30, 1898.

entries.fullText: All of us took luncheon or more properly dinner with Mrs Susan Snom Blarsdell- Mrs Shaffnes sider Miss Thomas a Nande Lain took election ban to Bangar-suffer at Nanger House & got home at 9:01 This enoys mail brought- cant proof of look and a cellar font - Crornwall Chilate-Echin Irmday Defortmal of Na New York Herald- asking me to let them have beaumift copy of my book- for them to try the first and largest review of course & send it on Er Mrs Harfer and to M D. M. Comfy hit- it shows great interest in our cause that N. J. Harda should wish to get a "scoop" on the otherhafers at Hamfallen at Mrs Naffnus
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about having lunch with Mrs. Susan Snom Blarsdell, Mrs. Shaffnes, Miss Thomas, and Lain. She also mentions receiving mail from the New York Herald asking for a copy of her book and Mrs. Harfer and M.D. M. Comfy showing interest in their cause. Lastly, she mentions being at Hamfallen at Mrs. Naffnus.

entries.fullText:
Jeff Hampden -- a Mrs. Hoffman drove us up to Dangor to take the P.M. train for Portland arrived there at 6 -- I found her [smede juan] waiting
stopped at Mrs. Thomas'
entries.summaryText: Jeff Hampden and Mrs. Hoffman travel to Dangor and Portland.

entries.fullText: Jeff Portland at 9 A.M. reached Boston behind time so missed the [ev.] train & took the 2 P.M. -- found Marin Luther Walker at Reeds Ferry Station -- and spent night with her at her friends or her home -- Mrs. Wheeler -- she is very pleasant situated -- is the out [later] of [haftens] Merritts wife -- Mary Luther
entries.summaryText: Jeff travels to Boston and meets with Marin Luther Walker at Reeds Ferry Station before spending the night with her and Mrs. Wheeler.

entries.fullText:
Left Reeds Ferry at 8.20 -
reached Concord at 10 &
found Parker & Helen
Pillsbury's only child -
Helen Pillsbury Coggswell - at
the station - spent the night
with her - at evg called on
Mrs A. S. White - found her at
the Universalist Church - staid
until all the slow men were
through - & then at 10 Oclock
they invited me to speak
which I did
It is very lonely for
dear Helen with her uncle
- her husband - her mother
all gone before & now
her father - so she is left only
with her girl Mary
in the house - every thing as
spank & clean as her
precious mother always had it
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Concord and spends the night with Helen Pillsbury Coggswell. She also visits Mrs. A. S. White at the Universalist Church and speaks there.

entries.fullText:
Rev. Anna H. Shaw -
to reach Rochester this day
for a weeks stay - to help
stir up sentiment for raising
the $100,000 to open the R. A.
doors to the girls!!

Left Concord at 8.50
or thereabouts & reached Boston
so that I called on Alice -
& then Frank Garrison who
took me to see the Shaw
monument on Beacon Hill -
then to Station through
the new underground tunnel
Electric cars - lunched -
saw me on train at 3-
I soon found I was but
to be hindered on account
of the washouts at Hosick
Falls - which I should have
escaped had I taken the
Boston & Albany R. R. instead
of the Fitchburg route
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Boston and sees the Shaw monument on Beacon Hill with Frank Garrison before leaving for Rochester.

entries.fullText:
Reached home at
4 P.M. - washed
dressed & dined - then
reached dear Mrs.
Emily Barnes Hollister's at 2 P.M.
the grand-daughter of
Thurlow Weed & daughter
Of Emily Weed Barnes of
Albany for a
parlor meeting in her
new & elegant home.
Mrs. Montgomery presided
& a University Prof. spoke
and myself - about
60 or 70 laides there -
entries.summaryText: Attended a parlor meeting at Mrs. Emily Barnes Hollister's home in Albany with about 60 or 70 ladies present.

entries.fullText:
At Home
at 2 P.M. held
a meeting at University
Hall - it was packed
Prof. --spoke--also
Jo Allning--Mrs [A?]
& self.
entries.summaryText: Held a meeting at University Hall with a packed audience where Prof., Jo Allning, Mrs [A?], and herself spoke.

entries.fullText:
At home -
Attended church
entries.summaryText: Attended church at home.

entries.fullText:
At Home
The Co. Education meeting
were broken off by the
illness of the tiller mens
of Mrs. Montgomerys
and the death also
entries.summaryText: The Co. Education meeting was interrupted due to illness and death.

entries.fullText:
DIED-At the residence of her daugh-
ter. Mrs. Wendell P. Mosher, Thursday
afternoon, Mrs. Mary P. Mixer. Her
daughters will talk her to Cleveland
this afternoon, where funeral services
will be held Sunday
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Mary P. Mixer passed away at the residence of her daughter, Mrs. Wendell P. Mosher. Funeral services will be held in Cleveland on Sunday.

entries.fullText:
At home [ ? ] and gets ready for [ ? ] -
too tired for anything-
[ ? ] drew union
from Mrs Fullam
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was at home and too tired to do anything. She received a union from Mrs. Fullam.

entries.fullText: DIED-At the residence of her daughter, Mrs. Wendell P. Mosher, Thursday afternoon, Mrs. Mary P. Mixer. Her daughters will take her to Cleveland this afternoon, where funeral services will be held Sunday.
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Mary P. Mixer died at the residence of her daughter, Mrs. Wendell P. Mosher. Funeral services will be held in Cleveland on Sunday.

entries.fullText:
at home larking & getting ready for event -
too tired for anything -
- travelling dress around for Mrs. Fillam -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was at home getting ready for an event and was too tired to do anything. She was working on a travelling dress for Mrs. Fillam.

entries.fullText: DIED - At the residence of her daughter, Mrs. Wendell P. Mosher, Thursday afternoon, Mrs. Mary P. Mixer. Her daughters will take her to Cleveland this afternoon, where funeral services will be held.
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Mary P. Mixer died at the residence of her daughter, Mrs. Wendell P. Mosher. Funeral services will be held in Cleveland.

entries.fullText:
At home and getting ready for __________ - too tired for anything
Travelling dress __________ from Mrs. Fillam
entries.summaryText: The author was at home and too tired to do anything. She received a travelling dress from Mrs. Fillam.

entries.fullText:
Left home [?]
Horse - & by Nickel Plate R. R.
for Chicago - 10.05 A.M. -
Sister May went Station
with me - - Paid
Annie Dann & G. L. Hawley
wages to end of October -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left home for Chicago with her sister May and paid Annie Dann and G. L. Hawley their wages.

entries.fullText:
Reached Chicago
at 7.50 - found Mrs
Gross' Julliann at
Station - & her at
the door of her home
to greet me -
after dinner went
to see cousin Melissa
Dickinson - then back
& at 8 - Mrs G. took
Dr. Sarah H. Stevenson &
me to the auditorium to
the victory Jubilee to see
Pr. McKinley - with all
the [?] & all the arches
on streets - not a thing
of women on them, man -
Took train at 10.20
& found it was slow - &
would not get me to St. Lo
until tomorrow night!! -
was too vexed with myself -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived in Chicago and met with Mrs. Gross' Julliann. She also visited her cousin Melissa Dickinson and attended the victory Jubilee to see Pr. McKinley. She took a train to St. Lo but was vexed to find out it was slow and would not arrive until the next day.

entries.fullText:
Mrs. Slate arrived meeting
St Joseph - this evg -
Ella Harrison - Pres
guest of Mrs Judge Kelley
1010 North 6th street - St Joseph
- Mrs Kelley mother of
14 children - 7 alive &
all grown up - adopted
7- also -! Rainy & cold -
- Left - [?] at 10.30
& dragged along all day
reaching St. Jo. at about 8 P.M
- refused to go into
hall - sent word Mrs Catt
must speak - went to Judge
Kelley's & soon was in
bed -
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Slate arrived at a meeting in St. Joseph and stayed with Mrs. Judge Kelley. It was rainy and cold and they reached St. Jo. at about 8 P.M. Mrs. Catt must speak but Mrs. Slate refused to go into the hall.

entries.fullText:
In St. Joseph -
went down to
[?] meeting in
forenoon - took a napp
in P.M. & made
my speech in evening -
- throat behaved very
badly - but managed
to get through by taking
a swallow of water
- - Mrs Catt & self
took sleeper at 12
midnight for Council
Bluffs -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony went to a meeting in St. Joseph and made a speech in the evening. Her throat behaved badly but she managed to get through by taking a swallow of water. She and Mrs. Catt took a sleeper at midnight for Council Bluffs.

entries.fullText:
The 27th Vote Suffrage Gone
to here at C,B, this day
Mrs Gatt (?) and self arrived
at C.A. at 5 A.M. and
went and walked - to the yy
home of Dr. and Mrs. Montgomery
whose guests we are -
Mrs Gatt went over to the
Omaha Exposition - was
chilled through - I went
to Ex. Com. meeting in
Baptist church - good
audience in evening- our old
friend D.G. Bloomer gave
address and welcome - my
throat had the hitch in it again.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her trip to Council Bluffs, Iowa, where she attended an Ex. Com. meeting in Baptist church and listened to D.G. Bloomer's address and welcome. She also mentions the Omaha Exposition and her throat problem.

entries.fullText: Paola - State Suffrage of Kansas - Ms. Stoddard Turner M. C. Church - guest of Ms. Dr. Uhls - he was physician at Osawatemie Assylum and knows Nettie Hawley & brothers there - a general dead feeling among the Kansas women.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Paola, Kansas and meets with Ms. Stoddard Turner and Ms. Dr. Uhls. They discuss the general feeling among Kansas women.

entries.fullText: Left Paola at 4:05 P.M. Miss Green the long time travelling agent of St Louis firm for [P?]&c on train Met J. Ellen Foster at K. City station - She is talking in Republican campaign in Kansas - asking Kansas women to work for Repub. party that voted in /94 against helping women to the right. Had great doubts whether to go to Leavenworth & stop over Sunday or on to Omaha - & see what is going on there - took train for O. at 9.15.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony leaves Paola, Kansas and meets with Miss Green and J. Ellen Foster at K. City station. She contemplates whether to stop over in Leavenworth or go straight to Omaha.

entries.fullText:
Arrived Omaha
at 6- found no room
not even a place to
wash and dress at the
Paxton. So took seat
in parlor to wait a
possible chance__
Soon Miss Shaw &
Lucy E. & Ms Sewall
& secretary arrived - &
all were settled - quite
comfortably - at 3. P.M.
We all went to Liberal
religious meeting-- heard
Rabbi Hirsch, Rev'd J. Lloyd
Jones & Dr Thomas - then
they called me out - & also
Miss Shaw - at evening MIss
Shaw preached in M.E. Church
Mr McLowns--& I attended
Jewish [?] meeting
all very nice--
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived in Omaha and attended a religious meeting where she heard several speakers and also preached at an evening meeting.

entries.fullText:
[Mrs C.B. Colby
Nebraska State meeting
Omaha Nebraska]
3d biennial Committee of
Women --Congregational
Church - Omaha - Exposition
Business meeting in
Cong. Church, Parlor --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attended a business meeting at the Congregational Church in Omaha, Nebraska as part of the Nebraska State meeting.

entries.fullText:
Wea. TUES, OCT. 25, 1898 Ther.
Nebraska State Com. Omaha
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote about the Nebraska State Committee meeting in Omaha on October 25, 1898.

entries.cityOrState:
Woman's National Convent
Omaha - Neb -
At Paxton Hotel -
entries.fullText:
Wea. WED. OCT. 26, 1898 Ther.
Woman's National Convent
Omaha - Neb -
At Paxton Hotel -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote about attending the Woman's National Convention in Omaha on October 26, 1898, which was held at the Paxton Hotel.

entries.fullText: Council of women -
entries.summaryText: Attended council of women.

entries.fullText: Council meeting -
entries.summaryText: Attended council meeting.

entries.fullText:
Council Business meeting
all the day long - & the
evening as well -
At 6 P.M. Mrs
Colfetzer called & took
me to dinner at her home
entries.summaryText: Council Business meeting all day. Had dinner at Mrs. Colfetzer's home.

entries.fullText:
In Omaha -
Miss Dervall took early
train for Lincoln -
Lucy E. Miss Shaw, Mrs Bailey
& self went to Unit- Church
to hear Mr N. M. Mann -
& I went to dinner
to Mr Montgomery
to dinner - Mrs Colby
there - Mr & Mrs M. took
me out to Exposition - met
Mr Mann & Mr Kilpatrick
- everything very beautiful -
- waited to see the grounds
lighted - then Mr Mann
took us to Paxton Hotel -
- Lucy came later
entries.summaryText: Attended church and dinner with friends. Visited the Exposition and saw the grounds lighted. Stayed at Paxton Hotel with Mr. Mann and others.

entries.fullText: Omaha [promised to attend woman's club at 3 P.M.] Lucy E and self left Omaha at 9:05 A.M.- Burlington R.R. arrived Leavenworth 2 P.M. found brother DR on east side--DR. Jr & wife Bessie Havens came to supper - she is a very lovely girl - Their Baby Eleania is six months old
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived in Leavenworth after visiting Omaha, where she had dinner with her brother DR and his family, including his lovely wife Bessie Havens and their six-month-old baby Eleania.

entries.fullText: In Leavenworth - at 5.00 Maud & Sister Annie - Lucy E & self went to nephew Dannies to DInner - he was off hunting - brother D.R. there also - saw the baby - they have a very small, cozy house--the little wife seems very happy
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony had dinner with her nephew Dannies, her brother D.R., and his family in their small and cozy house in Leavenworth.

entries.fullText:
Lucy E. & self left
Leavenworth 9.15
& reached Fort Scott
2.15 - brother Memitt
met us at station
with his hay ponies -
- Mary L had [?]
dinner waiting for us
entries.summaryText: Lucy E. and Susan B. Anthony travel from Leavenworth to Fort Scott and are met by Memitt and Mary L.

entries.fullText: In Fort Scott
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is in Fort Scott.

entries.fullText: Dr. [?] Scott called as Dr. Hall - who is ill with cold
entries.summaryText: Dr. [?] Scott visited to check on Dr. Hall who is ill with a cold.

entries.fullText: Dr. [?] Scott
entries.summaryText: Dr. [?] Scott was mentioned.

entries.fullText: Engaged to give a half hour talk to the Tuesday afternoon womans club the womans Raines called to invite me-Mrs Ruicklny is a member-nurty as Mrs Morgan's-readers for the day she Dayfoat and Mrs Counerse
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony has been invited to give a talk at the Tuesday afternoon woman's club. She was invited by Mrs. Raines and Mrs. Ruicklny, who is a member. She will be reading alongside Mrs. Dayfoat and Mrs. Counerse at Mrs. Morgan's.

entries.fullText:
Our Dear Mother's
105th Birthday
The 29th Anniversary of the
Hanging of Ol John Brown
Dec. 2, 1859 !!
And the day that
announces the burning (?)
of Old Corinthian Hall -
(this early morning) the
dear old Hall in which
so many great man and
women presented thier highest
thought to Rochester's best people
Phillips, Garrison, Beecher, Curtis,
- Mrs. Stanton- Mrs Rise, Lucy
Stone, Frances D Gage, Mrs
Clarina Howard Nichols -
in which the first N. Z. Mate
Temporary house of Morris was found
in April 1859
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about the 105th birthday of her mother, the 29th anniversary of the hanging of John Brown, and the burning of Old Corinthian Hall in Rochester, where many notable people, including Mrs. Stanton, Lucy Stone, and Frances D Gage, presented their thoughts to the city's people.

entries.fullText:
Sent $5 for charter
membership of Mr. George
Washington Memorial Association
- Mrs. Frank Dosttuf - Treas.
32 West 21st st New York US
Object, raising money to build
National University on the
grounds bequeathed to the
National government (?), for Nat purpose
by George Washington's last march.
Sent Mrs Fofalinn (?), Miss
Belle P Holden's check of $14 - 1000 James St-
Syracuse, NY. It came in
response to the letter. I signed
1,000 ofc. for Mrs. W. to send out
another card asking every woman who
earned money to send a dollar.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony sent $5 for charter membership of Mr. George Washington Memorial Association and a check of $14 to Mrs. Fofalinn for Miss Belle P Holden in response to a letter. She also signed 1,000 ofc. for Mrs. W. to send out another card asking every woman who earned money to send a dollar.

entries.fullText: Wea. Wed. .Dec. 14, 1898 Ther.

The P.E. Club's sociable
at our house this evening - a
big crowd - a good time -
gave notice of the coming
of Mrs Sewall - the 20th
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about hosting a sociable for the P.E. Club at her house, and mentions the upcoming visit of Mrs. Sewall on the 20th.

geographicalLocations: Parish house of St Pauls Church East
entries.fullText: a [?] - attended the Women's Ethical club at Parish house of St Pauls Church East [?]. Mrs Dr. Linn President- invited to speak on Our Mothers Days - & also to give notice of Mrs. Sewall's arriving the 20th
entries.summaryText: Attended Women's Ethical club meeting at Parish house of St Pauls Church East. Mrs Dr. Linn President invited to speak on Our Mothers Days and also to give notice of Mrs. Sewall's arriving the 20th.

entries.fullText: In P.M. went to the Watson House to reception & tea - guest of honor Miss Deyo - P.H.D. from University of Heidleburg. Mrs Fitzsimmons took me home in carriage - & is to take me to call on Father Kiernan - about local Council organization
entries.summaryText: Attended reception and tea at Watson House, guest of honor was Miss Deyo, P.H.D. from University of Heidleburg. Mrs Fitzsimmons took me home in carriage and is to take me to call on Father Kiernan about local Council organization.

entries.fullText:
At-home
attend Church - found
M. Brown - the new
pastor of Plymouth -
in the pulpit - in exchange
with Mr. Gannett -
he preached a splendid
sermon on Christ a Man -
if one could hope to reach
his excellence -
Mr Lee Burns came &
dined with us - roast
chicken - had satisfactory
talk about Bowen & Merrill Co,
& the book.
Catharine Curtis
Brewster - May Fish Curtis
daughter invited me to ride
in her sleigh - so she & Mrs.
Charlotte Curtis accompanied
me home - a lovely ride.
entries.summaryText: Attended church and had a satisfactory talk about Bowen & Merrill Co. with Mr. Lee Burns.

entries.fullText:
At home
Worked all day on
letters about Security [?]
Bdg.
entries.summaryText: Worked on letters about Security Bdg.

entries.fullText:
Mrs Fitzsimon's to
call for me at about
4 P.M.--two storing
spent the day writing
good words of greeting on
fly leaves of [nineteen?]
sets of Biography to be
sent by express to my
friends
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Fitzsimon's visit and writing good words of greeting on fly leaves of sets of Biography to be sent by express to my friends.

entries.fullText:
Mrs Fitzsimons called at
4 & took me to Father
Kiernan's of St Mary's--he
seemed very pleased at
idea of Local Council
then we called on the
Secretary Miss Coninne L.
Mahon--126--East Avenue
of the Plattsburg Catholic
School branches
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Fitzsimons visit to Father Kiernan's of St Mary's and the Secretary Miss Coninne L. Mahon of the Plattsburg Catholic School branches.

entries.fullText:
At home
Wrote on fly leaves
& sent out 21 - sets
of Biography
Received Express box
from Cousin Melissa
Dickinson - Chicago - with
1 doz great-huckabusk
towels - 1 doz napkins &
one table-cloth of the
liveliest & silkiest damask
One box of oranges &
a grape fruit from Rev
Anna Shaw - & niece Lucy E
ordered [?] Wm Stout -
May Hallowell & Sarah
Willis called & revealed
then how they came - Miss
Shaw ordered the oranges sent - by
William Stout
entries.summaryText: Received an express box from Cousin Melissa Dickinson with towels, napkins, and a table-cloth. Also received a box of oranges and a grapefruit from Rev Anna Shaw and niece Lucy E. May Hallowell and Sarah Willis visited.

entries.fullText:
At home
Writing on fly leaves
again - and Sister
May says enough
to make 70 sets in all -
sent out & given to friends
in city
entries.summaryText: Wrote on fly leaves and received enough from Sister May to make 70 sets of Biography, which were sent out and given to friends in the city.

entries.fullText:
Went to try on
Silecia [silesia, a type of fabric] with Coat
very nice indeed -
Mrs. Fullams -
Received letter &
$100 check from
dear Olivia Bigelow
Hall - Mrs. Israel Hall
Ann Arbor
From dear Rachel a white
apron - from Dr. Eliz. Sargent a
card with [?] - From Mr. &
Mrs. Gannett a card with good
quotation from Amelia
Willard - her picture
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about trying on fabric, receiving letters and checks from friends, and receiving gifts from acquaintances.

entries.fullText:
Went to Church.
Sister May also - Mr. Gannett
talked of the specific idea
of Christmas - & of its
general idea - every birth was
a miracle - so far as our knowing
the exact [?]
Both of us remained
at home & no one called
save a poor man wanting
15 cts for a night's lodging - his
breath was too strong of whiskey
to give him an order on Mr.
Miles - Salvation Army restaurant
on Exchange St
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about attending church on Christmas Day and a poor man who came to her home seeking lodging.

entries.fullText:
At home
Annie E. Dann & sister
Jennie Dann - go to Miss
Lela Heaths - at 2 oclock
to Christmas dinner - sent
Miss Heath a set of
the Biography - no one will
make them serve better
than she
Miss Rose
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony had Christmas dinner with Annie E. Dann, Jennie Dann, Miss Lela Heaths, and Miss Rose at home. She sent Miss Heath a set of the Biography.

entries.fullText:
Mrs Isabel C. Danows 115 East Ave - girls
school play - at Begne's Hall -
134 East Avenue - its at at 3 O clock
Room was very cold & Mercury
almost down to zero -
called at Mrs Sanfords
after the talk to the girls
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attended a girls' school play at Begne's Hall and visited Mrs. Sanford after talking to the girls. The room was very cold with the mercury almost down to zero.

entries.fullText:
The Irondequoit D.A.R's
meet at Mrs. Craig's - 39 South
Washington St - Dec 28 - at 3:30 P.M.
Florence Chase Newall Secy
Called on Mrs. Montgomery to talk of
Mrs. Sewall's lecture
then to Mrs. Fullams
to try on coat
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends a meeting of the Irondequoit D.A.R's at Mrs. Craig's, discusses Mrs. Sewall's lecture with Mrs. Montgomery, and tries on a coat at Mrs. Fullams.

entries.fullText:
At home
Summer day almost -
snow melting very rapidly
Took cloaks to Mrs.
Raphael
Found Miss
Hawley had gone to
the city Hospital
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends a summer day at home and takes cloaks to Mrs. Raphael, but finds out that Miss Hawley has gone to the city Hospital.

entries.fullText:
May Wright Sewall - of
633 - North Penn, of - Indianapolis-IN
lectures to women's clubs in the
Y.M.C.A. Music Hall - at 3 P.M.
Mrs. S arrived on 8.17
Northern Central train -
Post Express reporter came - Mrs
Fitch called for Mrs. S
to lunch with her tomorrow
Mrs. Hair's interview
very fine in this A.M.'s Dem & Chron
Dr. Raldrum called
to report on Miss Hawley

Mr. J. Renwick Seager, a well-known
authority on parliamentary and municipal
franchise, has just issued an eighth edition of his
book entitled " Notes on Registration." This is
a succinct elucidation of the Representation of
the People's Acts of 1867 and 1884, the Registration
Act 1885, the County Electors Act 1888, and the
Local Government Act 1894, together with a
digest of cases on appeal from 1884 to 1898. Beginning
as a mere pamphlet intended for the use
of Liberal committees, Mr. Seager's book has
developed into a solid manual which will be of
invaluable assistance to secretaries and agents of
political associations. It is divided into four
chapters--namely, Parliamentary Franchise,
Municipal Franchise, Claims, and Objections,
and is published (3s. 6d. net) by Messrs. Bemrose
and Sons. 23. Old Bailey.
entries.summaryText: A book entitled "Notes on Registration" by Mr. J. Renwick Seager has been published and will be of invaluable assistance to secretaries and agents of political associations.
